coredata.dc:title: Quantum escape of sudden future singularity
coredata.dc:creator: Nojiri, Shin'ichi
Odintsov, Sergei D.
coredata.dc:description: AbstractWe consider finite-time, future (sudden or Big Rip type) singularities which may occur even when strong energy condition is not violated but equation of state parameter is time-dependent. Recently, example of such singularity has been presented by Barrow, we found another example of it. Taking into account back reaction of conformal quantum fields near singularity, it is shown explicitly that quantum effects may delay (or make milder) the singularity. It is argued that if the evolution to singularity is realistic, due to quantum effects the universe may end up in de Sitter phase before scale factor blows up. This picture is generalized for braneworld where sudden singularity may occur on the brane with qualitatively similar conclusions.

head.ce:title: Quantum escape of sudden future singularity

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Applied Physics, National Defence Academy, Hashirimizu Yokosuka 239-8686, Japan

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: InstituciÃ² Catalana de Recerca i Estudis AvanÃ§ats (ICREA), Barcelona, Spain

ce:affiliation.ce:label: c
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Institut d'Estudis Espacials de Catalunya (IEEC), Edifici Nexus, Gran CapitÃ 2-4, 08034 Barcelona, Spain

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We consider finite-time, future (sudden or Big Rip type) singularities which may occur even when strong energy condition is not violated but equation of state parameter is time-dependent. Recently, example of such singularity has been presented by Barrow, we found another example of it. Taking into account back reaction of conformal quantum fields near singularity, it is shown explicitly that quantum effects may delay (or make milder) the singularity. It is argued that if the evolution to singularity is realistic, due to quantum effects the universe may end up in de Sitter phase before scale factor blows up. This picture is generalized for braneworld where sudden singularity may occur on the brane with qualitatively similar conclusions.

ce:section.ce:para: The knowledge of the dark energy equation of state parameter w is extremely important due to various reasons. According to current astrophysical data this parameter is close (above or below) toÂ â1. If it less than â1 then such dark energy (of phantom sort) drives the universe to finite time future singularity (Big Rip) [1â3] with catastrophic consequences for future civilizations. According to various estimations in this case the universe will exist for several more billions of years at best, before ending up in a cosmic doomsday. How realistic is such sudden future singularity? Is it common property of only dark energy with w less thanÂ â1? The partial answer to second question is given in the recent paper [4] where it was shown that even for usual matter (and when strong energy condition is not violated!) the sudden future singularity may occur.

In the present Letter we argue that near to future singularity the quantum effects may become dominant and they can stop (or delay) the finite time future singularity (for general discussion of classical singularities, see bookÂ [5]). The same occurs for brane sudden singularities. This indicates that future Quantum Gravity era is quite possible and deserves some attention. In principle, the proof that sudden singularity does not occur maybe quite simple. Indeed, one should write quantum-corrected FRW equations at late time and show that there is stable non-singular solution (at some conditions). For instance, such strategy in case of trace anomaly driven inflation model shows that universe evolves to non-singular deÂ Sitter space. We go even further, taking into account quantum effects contribution as back-reaction near the future singularity. Even in such complicated formulation, there are indications that finite time singularity is soften (or delayed).

Let us consider the generalization of Barrow's model [4]. In this model, the matter has been given implicitly via the FRW equations: (1)Ï=6Îº2H2,p=â2Îº22dHdt+3H2. The spatially-flat FRW metric is considered (2)ds2=âdt2+a(t)2âi=1,2,3dxi2, and Hâ¡1adadt. Eq. (1) shows that Ï is always positive.

We now assume H has the following form: (3)H(t)=HÌ(t)+Aâ²tsâtÎ±. Here HÌ is a smooth, differentiable (infinite number of times, in principle) function and Aâ² and ts are constants. Another assumption is that a constant Î± is not a positive integer. Then H(t) has a singularity at t=ts. In case Î± is negative integer, the singularity is pole. Even if Î± is positive, in case Î± is not an integer, there appears cut-like singularity. It is important for us that singularity presents. If we can consider the region t>ts, there is no finite-time future singularity. One also assumes the singularity belongs to the typeÂ (3) although there are other types of singularities, say, logarithmic ones.
When Î±>1, one gets (4)Ïâ¼âpâ¼6Îº2HÌ(ts)2. Hence w=p/Ï=â1, which may correspond to the positive cosmological constant.

The case 0<Î±<1 corresponds to Barrow's model and when tâ¼ts, we find (5)Ïâ¼6Îº2HÌ(ts)2,pâ¼Â±4Aâ²Î±Îº2|tsât|Î±â1. Here the plus sign in Â± corresponds to t<ts case and the minus one to t>ts. In the following, the upper (lower) sign always corresponds to t<ts (t>ts). The parameter of equation of state w is given by (6)w=Â±23Aâ²Î±|tsât|Î±â1HÌ(ts)2. Then it follows that w is positive in two cases: one is Aâ²>0 and t<ts, which directly corresponds to Barrow's model, and another is Aâ²<0,t>ts. In other cases, w is negative.

When â1<Î±<0, the energy density Ï and the pressure is given by (7)Ï=6Aâ²2Îº2|tsât|2Î±,pâ¼Â±4Aâ²Î±Îº2|tsât|Î±â1. The parameter of equation of state is (8)w=Â±2Î±3Aâ²|tsât|âÎ±â1, which diverges at t=ts. Here w is positive when Aâ²>0 and t<ts or Aâ²<0 and t>ts. The former case corresponds to future singularity even if w is positive. The singularity can be regarded as a Big Rip. (For the recent comparison of phantom Big Rip with above type of it, seeÂ [6]. The mechanisms to escape of phantom Big Rip were suggested in Refs. [7,10].)

The case Î±=â1 gives (9)Ï=6Aâ²2Îº2|tsât|â2,pâ¼â2Îº2Â±2Aâ²+3Aâ²2|tsât|â2, which may correspond to the scalar field with exponential potential. The parameter w is given by (10)w=â1â2Aâ². Near t=ts, the universe is expanding if Aâ²>0 and t<ts or Aâ²<0 and t>ts. The former case corresponds to the phantom with w<â1. In the latter case, if 2>Aâ²>0, the equation of state describes the usual matter with positive w and if Aâ²>2, the matter may be the quintessence with 0>w>â1.
If Î±<â1, one obtains (11)Ï=âp=6Aâ²2Îº2|tsât|2Î±, which gives w=â1 as for the cosmological constant case. In this case, however, there is rather strong singularity at t=ts.

We should note that w is not constant in general. When w is constant, except the case w=â1, the energy density Ï and the pressure p are given by (9) and always behave as |tsât|â2. If we consider only expanding universe (not shrinking one), the future singularity appears when w<â1, which corresponds to phantom. In the case with constant w>â1, there does not appear the future singularity in the expanding universe although there is past or initial singularity at t=ts.

Notice that usually w=â1 corresponds to cosmological constant presence but in general, in case that wââ1 when tâts there can appear a singularity in the expanding universe as inÂ (4) andÂ (11). In case ofÂ (4), the singularity is rather mild, and H and dHdt (orÂ a, dadt, and d2adt2) are finite and d2Hdt2 (or d3adt3) diverges at t=ts. On the other hand, the case (11) shows very strong singularity, where the scale factor a behaves as aâeâAâ²Î±+1|tsât|Î±+1.

On the contrary, when w is not constant but varies with t, even if the strong energy condition (12)Ïm>0,Ïm+3pm>0 is satisfied, there can be a future singularity. An example is given in [4], which corresponds toÂ (5). We have found another example given in (7) with Aâ²>0 and t<ts.

When approaching the sudden future singularity, the curvature invariants grow and typical energies increase. This indicates that quantum effects (or even quantum gravity effects) should become significant near future singularity. They are usually associated with higher derivative terms. Imagine that quantum effects of conformal fields are dominant, as it occurs in some models of early universe, like in the trace anomaly driven inflationÂ [8]. Let us take into account the conformal anomaly contribution as back-reaction near singularity. The correspondent energy density ÏA and pressure pA are (see, for instance,Â [9]) (13)ÏA=â6bâ²H4â23b+bâ³â6Hd2Hdt2â18H2dHdt+3dHdt2,(14)pA=bâ²6H4+8H2dHdt+23b+bâ³â2d3Hdt3â12Hd2Hdt2â18H2dHdtâ9dHdt2. In general, with N scalar, N1/2 spinor, N1 vector fields, N2(=0or1) gravitons and NHD higher derivative conformal scalars, b, bâ² and bâ³ are given by (15)b=N+6N1/2+12N1+611N2â8NHD120(4Ï)2,bâ²=âN+11N1/2+62N1+1411N2â28NHD360(4Ï)2,bâ³=0. We should note b>0 and bâ²<0 for the usual matter except the higher derivative conformal scalars.

Near the (future) singularity, the curvatures and their derivatives with respect to t become large. Since the quantum correction includes the powers of the curvatures and their t-derivatives, the correction becomes large and important near the singularity. It may occur that it delays (or stop) the singularity in the analogy with trace anomaly driven inflationÂ [8].

As the first example, Barrow's model [4] is discussed. Following [4], we first consider the case that the scale factor a(t) is given by (16)a(t)=A+Btq+C(tsât)n. Here A>0, B>0, q>0, and ts>0 are constants and C=âAtsân. One also assumes t<ts and 2>n>1. There appears a singularity when tâts, where 1ad2adt2â+â. Since (17)H=qBtqâ1âCn(tsât)nâ1A+Btq+C(tsât)nâ¼qBtsqâ1A+BtsqâCn(tsât)nâ1A+Btsq, when tâ¼ts, the parameters in (3) correspond to (18)Aâ²=âCnA+Btsq,Î±=nâ1. The classical FRW equations (19)6Îº2H2=Ïm,2Îº2ad2adt2=âÏm+3pm6, show that (20)Ïmâ¼6q2B2ts2qâ2Îº2(A+Btsq)>0,pmâ¼âCn(nâ1)(tsât)nâ2A+Btsq>0, near the singularity tâ¼ts. The energy density Ïm is finite but the pressure pm diverges. Singularity presents but the strong energy condition (12) is satisfied since Ï and p are positive.

With the account of the quantum corrections (13) and (14), the classical FRW equationsÂ (19) are modified as (21)6Îº2H2=Ïm+ÏA,2Îº2ad2adt2=âÏm+ÏA+3pm+3pA6. As clear from the expressions (13) and (14), ÏA and pA become singular at t=ts. It follows fromÂ (21) (22)Ïmâ¼âÏAâ¼623b+bâ³BCqn(nâ1)(nâ2)tsqâ1(tsât)nâ3(A+Btsq)2>0,pmâ¼âpAâ¼223b+bâ³Cn(nâ1)(nâ2)(nâ3)(tsât)nâ4A+Btsq<0. Thus, the energy density Ïm is positive but diverges at t=ts. Since the pressure pm is negative and more singular than Ïm, the strong energy condition (12) is violated and also Ï+p<0.

For the example (20), the singularity at t=ts might become milder due to the quantum correction. To see this, we assume 4>n>3, instead of 2>n>1, inÂ (16). For this choice a, dadt, d2adt2, and d3adt3 are finite when t=ts but d4adt4 diverges there. Then the singularity is rather milder than the case 2>n>2, where d2adt2 diverges. Using (21) around t=ts, one gets (23)Ïm=6Îº2H2âÏAâ¼6q2B2ts2qâ2Îº2(A+Btsq)â6bâ²B4q4ts4qâ4(A+Btsq)4â323b+bâ³âB2q2(qâ1)(qâ3)ts2qâ4(A+Btsq)2â2B3q3(qâ1)ts3qâ4(A+Btsq)3+3B4q4ts4qâ4(A+Btsq)4,pmâ¼âpAâ¼223b+bâ³Cn(nâ1)(nâ2)(nâ3)(tsât)nâ4A+Btsq. In the above expression, Ïm is not positive in general. However, in a special case b=âbâ²>0, q=1, it reduces to (24)Ïmâ¼6B2Îº2(A+Bts), which is positive. pm in (23) is, however, negative since C=âAtsân<0 inÂ [4]. In principle, there is no any strong reason to exclude the case that C is positive. In the case C>0, if one replaces (25)223b+bâ³Cn(nâ1)(nâ2)(nâ3)ââCn(nâ1),nân+2, in pm (23), we obtain pm (20). The arguments may be reversed. If we start with the matter (20) (say, with q=1), due to the quantum correction, we obtain the following scale factor a (instead ofÂ (16)): (26)a(t)=A+Bt+Câ²(tsât)nâ². Here A>0, B>0, C>0, and ts>0 are constants and 4>nâ²>3. This demonstrates that the singularity becomes much milder due to the quantum correction.

In general, near the singularity ÏA becomes dominant. The natural assumption is then (27)Ïâ¼âÏA. For the case given in (7), we find (28)H(t)=HÌâ²(t)+Aâ²|tsât|2Î±+1. Here HÌâ²(t) is a smooth and differentiable function and Aâ² satisfies the following equation: (29)A2Îº2=â223b+bâ³HÌâ²(ts)(2Î±+1)Î±Aâ²>0. For the matter corresponding to (7), H behaves as Hâ¼|tsât|â1â¼0 but with the account of the quantum correction, one obtains Hâ¼|tsât|â1â¼1. Thus, the singularity becomes milder under quite general conditions. One should not forget that account of quantum gravity corrections (see recent example in [10]) may improve the situation with the singularity occurrence even more. Finally, the quantum effective action which is usually non-local and higher-derivative typically leads to violation of energy conditions on quantum level. Hence, in many cases it may support the singularities. Nevertheless, it is interesting that like in anomaly driven inflation there occur the stable regimes where quantum effects may drive (at least, partially) the future universe out of the singularity. Moreover, like in anomaly-driven inflation (with correspondent boundary conditions) one may argue that even future deÂ Sitter universe is quite realistic possibility as the corresponding solution of quantum-corrected FRW equation exists.

It is interesting that the above consideration of sudden future singularity may be easily generalized for brane-world models (for recent review, see [9,11,12] and references therein). Let the 3-brane is embedded into the 5d bulk space as inÂ [13]. Let gÎ¼Î½ be the metric tensor of the bulk space and nÎ¼ be the unit vector normal to the 3-brane. The metric qÎ¼Î½ induced on the brane has the following form: (30)qÎ¼Î½=gÎ¼Î½ânÎ¼nÎ½. The initial action is (31)S=â«d5xâg1Îº52R(5)â2Î+â¯+Sbrane(q). Here, the 5d quantities are denoted by the suffix (5) and 4d ones by (4). In (31), â¯ expresses the matter contribution and Sbrane is the action on the brane, which will be specified later. The bulk Einstein equation is given by (32)1Îº52R(5)Î¼Î½â12gÎ¼Î½R(5)=TÎ¼Î½. If one chooses the metric near the brane as: (33)ds2=dÏ2+qÎ¼Î½dxÎ¼dxÎ½, the energyâmomentum tensor TÎ¼Î½ has the following form: (34)TÎ¼Î½=TÎ¼Î½bulkmatterâÎgÎ¼Î½+Î´(Ï)(âÎ»qÎ¼Î½+ÏÎ¼Î½). Here TÎ¼Î½bulkmatter is the energyâmomentum tensor of the bulk matter, Î is the bulk cosmological constant, Î» is the tension of the brane, and ÏÎ¼Î½ expresses the contribution due to brane matter. Without the bulk matter (TÎ¼Î½bulkmatter=0), following the procedure inÂ [13], the bulk Einstein equation can be mapped into the equation on the brane: (35)1Îº52R(4)Î¼Î½â12qÎ¼Î½R(4)=â12Î+Îº52Î»26qÎ¼Î½+Îº52Î»6ÏÎ¼Î½+Îº52ÏÎ¼Î½â1Îº52EÎ¼Î½. Here ÏÎ¼Î½ is given by (36)ÏÎ¼Î½=â14ÏÎ¼Î±ÏÎ½Î±+112ÏÏÎ¼Î½+18qÎ¼Î½ÏÎ±Î²ÏÎ±Î²â124qÎ¼Î½Ï2. On the other hand, EÎ¼Î½ is defined by the bulk Weyl tensor C(5)Î¼Î½ÏÏ but as the bulk spacetime is anti-deÂ Sitter one, where the Weyl tensor vanishes, we put EÎ¼Î½=0. Like in [14] the tension of the brane Î» is fine-tuned to be (37)0=Î+Îº52Î»26. The metric on the brane is supposed to be the FRW metric (2). Let the energy density Ïm and the pressure pm of the matter on the brane are given as inÂ (20): (38)Ïtt=Ïm2,Ïij=pm2a2Î´ij,Ïmâ¼Ï0,pmâ¼p0(tsât)âÏµ. Here Ï0>0, p0>0, and 1>Ïµ>0 are constants. Then the strong energy condition (12) is satisfied. Now the effective Einstein equation (35) has the following form: (39)6Îº2H2=Ïm+Îº5224Ïm2,2Îº2ad2adt2=âÏm+3pm6+Îº52723pmÏm+2Ïm2. Here (40)Îº2â¡Î»Îº526. When tâ¼ts, one gets (41)Hâ¼Îº26Ï0+Îº5224Ï02,2Îº2ad2adt2â¼âpm2+Îº5224pmâ¼âp021+Îº52Ï012(tsât)âÏµ, which shows quantitatively the same behavior with that given by (16) with the following identification (42)Ï0=6q2B2ts2qâ2Îº2(A+Btsq),p0=âCn(nâ1)A+Btsq,Ïµ=2ân. Hence, even for the brane-world, the qualitative behavior of the singularity is not changed (for earlier discussion of finite time singularities in brane-world, seeÂ [15]).

The contribution from the conformal anomaly as a quantum correction from the matter on the brane may be again included. This can be done by replacing Ïm and pm in (39) with Ïm+ÏA and pm+pA, respectively. Near singularity tâ¼ts, one gets (43)pmâ¼âpA, that is, (44)p0(tsât)âÏµâ¼223b+bâ³d3Hdt3, which gives (45)H=23b+bâ³p0(tsât)3âÏµ2(1âÏµ)(2âÏµ)(3âÏµ)+HÌ(t). Here HÌ(t) is a smooth, differentiable (at least, three times) function. Hence, the qualitative behavior is similar to that given by (26) with identification (46)Ïµ=4ânâ². Thus, the singularity becomes much milder. The quantum effects of conformal matter help to realize the scenario of brane inflation called Brane New World [16â18]. As it follows from above consideration, the account of such quantum effects may help to avoid (or, at least to delay) the future sudden singularity. Moreover, as anomaly driven brane inflationary solution of FRW equations exists [16â18], one can argue that at similar conditions the future brane universe ends up in deÂ Sitter phase.

The final picture (if realistic) looks quite strange. The quantum gravity era of the early universe helps in the realization of inflation. Subsequently, after quite complicated history the universe evolves to dark energy dominated phase which eventually may evolve to sudden singularity. The approach to finite-time future singularity brings back to life the Quantum Gravity era. In its turn, quantum effects may stop further evolution into the singularity what decreases the typical energies. In the resulting, non-singular universe the quantum effects become negligible. Eventually, new circle of inflation (deflation) starts. This all reminds very much the oscillating universe.
